What the heck are you talking about? The way for ordinary middle class workers to save for retirement is if they are paid middle class wages. A lot of ink has been given over to theories that are crazier than this one. The idea of a "mechanical failure" or "catastrophic event" is totally at odds with the fact that the infamous left turn was programed BEFORE the copilot made his last "ok, good night". And, that further programming was done as the plane headed from waypoint to waypoint. A pilot suicide that involves flying around for 7 hours before crashing? In every other pilot suicide (mass murder) the guy points the plane's nose down, says his prayers and that's the end of it.

Let's posit, not a remotely controlled aircraft, but malware that was placed in the FMS to program changes, possibly spoof the pilots and knock everyone out through a steep climb and possibly cabin depressurization.

But all of that requires manual input or can be overridden by manual input? I thought I needed manual input to turn on my laptop webcam and start filming but it turns out that the NSA can place malware on selected computers that turns on the webcam without turning on the green light.

Is the FMS hack-proof? That's what Iran thought about their nuclear reactors until Stuxnet.

But why would anyone do this? Here's the good part. The organization or nation that devised this hyper-complicated worm on the cutting-edge of technology wanted to see whether it in fact works before applying it to more high-profile targets. That's why the plane crashed in the Indian Ocean, one of the "world's most inaccessible regions".

@LaBelleRebelle - Yes! It was a dry run used to affirm that it could be done. And it will be done again, only next time the choice of planes will be based on a target rather than simply choosing one because of how easily it could be redirected to such a remote part of the world.

Every theory I have read so far has some holes. It this was a dry run by some computer hacker, which was obviously successful more than 15 days ago, the presumed successful computer hackers would have by now struck their real intended target before the world figures out their exact methodology, and takes remedial measures.

"Boeing’s first fly-by-wire commercial aircraft, in which electronic controls replaced manual ones."

And therein lies the answer. The plane's changes in direction were programmed. The first one clearly was, but then communications ended. If the plane is found in the search area it will have ended up running out of fuel over one of the most remote areas on the planet.

The timing of everything fits. The first turn is made as communications switch from one country to another and communications go dead before the pilots recognize what's happened and then the hacked program makes the plane go to an altitude that incapacitates humans and then makes one final turn, so that when it runs out of fuel it will not be easily found.

It makes it all make sense. Except that it's really scary because "computer hackers" don't necessarily have national allegiances. Except when they do.

There's not a lot of ink given over to this idea, but what there is is emphatic that it is extremely unlikely that someone managed to hack the controls of a jumbo jet. What goes unsaid - and ignored - is that they are acknowledging that it could be done.

I always find it strange to see people writing books that say we are "on the road" towards some penultimate result that turns out to be identical to what we see around us today.
Be that as it may, if you say this book has some awesome modeling, I believe you. It is, perhaps, only where the author steps away from his strengths and starts delving in topics outside of his specialty that we see the inevitable tiny missteps here and there.

A good analogy would be Richard Dawkins, an excellent and rigorous biologist and passionate atheist, Prof.Dawkins often puts his foot wrong when talking about physics, for example, yet where his knowledge is solid, so is his analysis.

It is ironic for me to point this out, since I put my foot wrong almost every day, regardless of knowledge.
But irony is everywhere and not a drop to drink.

As a psychologist, I have worked with both victims and perpetrators, and also with attorneys traumatized by exposure to the details of these horrific crimes.

The perpetrators I have worked with have all been victims themselves who never got help to deal with their own trauma until they got caught. They all hated themselves for what they did. They felt ashamed and alienated from everyone and the only way they knew how to connect with other people was sexually. That's one of the problems. When you are sexualized at a young age, sex is the way you learn to connect. You don't realize until later how inappropriate it is and have no idea how to connect with people without sex and are too ashamed to ask for help so you just keep doing it until you are caught.

Another problem is that young children who are sexualized inside a family are not likely to have an improved situation even if they are removed from the family. I have seen far too many adults who were indeed removed from abusive families and then abused again by others mistakenly trusted to do better.

The sad thing is how common this is and how much damage it causes to entire lives and future relationships with the traumatized person.

The good news is that recovery from trauma is possible if you find at least one adult who can truly be trusted, at least one good experienced therapist, and then add time, patience, and love.

Workers Are Overtaxed

The claim, "America’s top one percent still owes its high incomes largely to compensation rather than wealth" cannot be supported by the numbers because the numbers don't exist. By this I mean there is only a survey every three years which enables the government to link net wealth to both unreported economic income (including inheritance) and reported taxable income and other demographic data.

For example, Warren Buffett has economic income (including unrealized capital gains) of about $3 billion a year not reported to the IRS but he only has taxable income of $30 or $40 million a year. Mr. Buffett, like many at the top can determine if he wants taxable income in the form of dividends or salary or perhaps he will take just a little bit of spending money. [Corporations can also defer taxes]. In fact, Mr. Buffet can give away a billion dollars (in stock) to a charity and claim a deduction for the full appreciated value. If the charity sells the stock (which is not often sold) for a good price, the market value of Mr. Buffet's remaining shares can increase much more than the actual value of the stock that was given away.

Bill Gates is another charitable fellow and a Democrat who last week told Mr. Brooks at AEI that the job killing payroll taxes need to go in order to create full employment. Social Security or Medicare stay the same. The revenue could be replaced by a VAT. We won't blame the Democrats for high payroll taxes and high unemployment.

I've always thought Vick was a sort of sacrificial victim for white America's discomfort with its black athletic heroes. In Vick's rather backward Southern rural culture, dogfighting was considered sporting and glamorous,  just as bullfighting in Spain seemed sporting and glamorous to Hemingway 90 years ago, so Vick saw himself not as some evil person but as a sportsman. The real reasons whites resent black football players all sound like racist stereotypes -- their lack of preparation for being college students, their high rates of sexual assault on white coeds, and so forth -- so those are largely unmentionable in polite society. For whites to get furiously mad at a black jock over dogfighting, however, can't be denounced as racist, so a lot of white anger at black athletes in general was focused upon Vick.

So outside of ulcer drugs, pain killers, and tranquilizers; how many more drugs does one regularly need to keep a horse safely on a track?

And regarding the barrage of images dead horses that you find misrepresent the industry, can you tell us if the NY Times statistic of 1200 horses dying on US racetracks in a week is accurate? So how many week's worth of dead horses did we see or hear of on PETA's video? Less than a week's worth?

And what exactly lead to the colic in Nehro? Was it inevitable? Or was it linked to the drugs, the NSAIDs, the training regimen, the anxiety, the feed, the hours in stalls? What are the most common causes of colic in racehorses specifically, say in contrast to a wild horse? Surely as a professional you can answer that.

Over 10,000 Thoroughbreds every year end up slaughtered for meat at very young ages. They do not get put out to pasture, or paid back in kind for their service. Even million dollar earners end up dying early deaths in slaughter plants when they no longer can produce foals, just like Ferdinand did.

The dirty little secret isn't just the drugs at the track, or the deaths from how they are trained and run. Go follow a truck from a pick up at a TB barn to a kill buyer's auction to a slaughter plants. Then tell me how wonderfully TBs are treated.

Some of the lucky ones "fall off" the TB trucks and auctions, and end up with rescues. We have code just like the trainers do. The death walk when they've given up, but we've brought them back. Sometimes our maquinas are hoists we use to try to pick them up, to support them when they are too weak to stand, it's harder to save them when they go down. The TB head bob - one of a host of compulsive behaviors they show from their unnatural lives.

This is the stuff nightmares are made of. TBs need what all horses need, and nothing different: A place in the herd, water, long hours of grazing, covering some ground in a day without a rider on its back, the safety of the herd to sleep. They have no changed in an evolutionary fashion like wolves to dogs. Domestic horses need what wild horses need. TBs are no different.
